stem: The nurse is caring for a patient at risk for suicide. For each nursing intervention, determine whether it is indicated or contraindicated for this patient.

itemContext.sbar: S: James Miller, a 32-year-old male, was admitted at 03:00 after a suicide attempt by overdose of acetaminophen. He was found by his roommate and brought to the ED. The patient reports feeling hopeless after losing his job and breaking up with his girlfriend. He has a history of depression, managed with sertraline, but stopped taking it two months ago. B: Patient reports a previous suicide attempt five years ago. Denies any other medical conditions. A: On assessment at 07:00, patient is oriented to person and place, but not time. He is tearful, withdrawn, and expresses feelings of worthlessness. Vital signs are stable. He denies current suicidal ideation, but states, "I just don't see things getting better." Labs show elevated liver enzymes, consistent with acetaminophen overdose. R: Continue to monitor for suicidal ideation. Implement suicide precautions. Consult with psychiatry. Administer prescribed acetylcysteine (Mucomyst) per protocol. Encourage patient to verbalize feelings.

tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content: AST: 650 U/L; ALT: 800 U/L; Acetaminophen level: 30 mcg/mL (drawn 03:30); WBC: 7.5; platelets: 250

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: Acetylcysteine (Mucomyst) 140mg/kg PO Loading Dose @ 04:00; Acetylcysteine (Mucomyst) 70mg/kg PO Maintenance Dose Q4H x 17 doses (scheduled); Sertraline 50mg PO Daily (hold)

topicTags: Mental Health: Suicide Risk & Crisis Management

rationale.correct: Providing a safe environment reduces the opportunity for self-harm. Continuous observation allows for immediate intervention if suicidal ideation escalates. Encouraging expression of feelings can help the patient process emotions and identify coping mechanisms. Consulting with psychiatry provides specialized expertise in managing mental health crises. Administering medications as prescribed addresses the physical consequences of the overdose.
rationale.incorrect: Leaving the patient alone increases the risk of self-harm. Ignoring verbal cues of distress can lead to missed opportunities for intervention and escalate suicidal ideation. Delaying psychiatric consultation delays access to specialized mental health care. Withholding medications can exacerbate the medical complications from the overdose. Focusing solely on the physical symptoms without addressing the underlying psychological distress neglects a crucial aspect of the patient's care.
clinicalPearls: A patient denying current suicidal ideation does not negate the need for suicide precautions, especially after a recent attempt.
Elevated liver enzymes in the lab values directly correlate to the acetaminophen overdose mentioned in the SBAR.

questionTrap.trap: Students may focus solely on the acetaminophen overdose and miss the underlying suicide risk.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Carefully consider the patient's history of depression, recent stressors, and the context of the overdose, even if the patient denies current suicidal ideation.

mnemonic.title: IS PATH WARM
mnemonic.expansion: Ideation, Substance Abuse, Purposelessness, Anxiety, Trapped, Hopelessness, Withdrawal, Anger, Recklessness, Mood Change

Leave the patient alone to respect their privacy
